newsitem.title: FRANCE: Arthuis-Maastricht must be strictly interpreted.
newsitem.headline: Arthuis-Maastricht must be strictly interpreted.

text.p: French Finance Minister Jean Arthuis repeated on Monday that Maastricht-treaty criteria for entry into European monetary union must be strictly interpreted.
"France's position has never wavered on this issue and it will not change," he said in an interview with financial daily L'Agefi.
President Jacques Chirac had repeated France's position at the start of the month, he said. "We want a strict application of the timetable and the criteria, as they are set out in the treaty."
Asked whether Italy would qualify for the single currency in 1999, he said he could not say which countries would join monetary union first.
"The one thing that seems to me without question is that France and Germany will be among the first, since they will meet all the (Maastricht) criteria," he said.
"As regards the others, I will make two comments -- first of all we would like the list (of participating countries) which will be decided at the start of 1998 to be as big as possible.
"But it is up to every state to take the necessary measures to be ready in time," he said.
Those who did not qualify for monetary union on January 1, 1999, should join as soon as possible afterwards.
"In the scale of history, for it is indeed a historic step that is being taken, one or two years is not necessarily a dramatic delay," he said.
